persons.name: JesusChrist
persons.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

persons.name: Xenophanes
persons.description: Greek philosopher, theologian, poet, and critic of Homer from Ionia who travelled throughout the Greek-speaking world in early Classical Antiquity. As a poet, Xenophanes was known for his critical style, writing poems that are considered among the first satires.

persons.name: Herodotus
persons.description: Greek historian and geographer who wrote a detailed account of the Greco-Persian Wars - one the earliest existing historical texts.

places.name: Sicily
places.description: Sicily is the largest and most populous island in the Mediterranean Sea and one of the twenty regions of Italy.

persons.name: Lucretius
persons.description: Roman poet and philosopher. His only known work is the materialist philosophical poem De rerum natura.

persons.name: Strabo
persons.description: Greek geographer, philosopher, and historian who lived in Asia Minor during the transitional period of the Roman Republic into the Roman Empire.

persons.name: Pliny
persons.description: The Elder. Roman army officer and author who wrote an encyclopedic Natural History. Died in the aftermath of the eruption of Vesuvius.

persons.name: AlbertusMagnus
persons.description: Wrote on natural philossophy. alchemy and much else besides. Bishop of Regensburg (Ratisbon), 1260-1262 and from 1931 a Doctor of the Church.

places.name: Cologne
places.description: city spanning the Rhine River in western Germany

persons.name: RobertPlot
persons.description: Robert Plot was an English naturalist and antiquarian who was the first professor of chemistry at the University of Oxford and the first keeper of the Ashmolean Museum.

persons.name: ThomasBrowne
persons.description: Seventeenth-century writer, especially on the natural world.

persons.name: EdwardLhuyd
persons.description: Geologist, naturalist and botanist, assistant to Robert Plot at the Ashmolean Museum, Fellow of the Royal Society

persons.name: RobertHooke
persons.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

persons.name: RobertHooke
persons.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

persons.name: JohnRay
persons.description: A Christian English naturalist widely regarded as one of the earliest of the English parson-naturalists. Until 1670, he wrote his name as John Wray. FRS.

persons.name: JohnWoodward
persons.description: Natural philospher with an interest in geology. His collection of fossils and minerals is part of Cambridge University's Sedgwick Museum of Geology. FRSL.

persons.name: Déodat Gratet deDolomieu
persons.description: French geologist. The rock, and region of the Alps, dolomite was named after him.

persons.name: Johan GottschalkWallerius
persons.description: A Swedish chemist and mineralogist.

persons.name: Abraham GottlobWerner
persons.description: German geologist who proposed the theory of Neptunism and who also proposed the chronological sequence found in stratified rocks.

persons.name: Johann HeinrichPott
persons.description: Prussian physician and chemist.

persons.name: Jean-AndréDeluc
persons.description: Swiss-born geologist, natural philosopher and meteorologist who spent much of his time working in England. FRSL.

persons.name: Torbern OlafBergman
persons.description: Swedish chemist and mineralogist. At some point Davy acquired a set of letters from Bergman to Franz Schwediaur written in the 1780s which are retained in the Royal Institution (RI MS HD/27/A). ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Martin HeinrichKlaproth
persons.description: Pharmacist and chemist. Professor of Chemistry in Berlin. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Jean-AndréDeluc
persons.description: Swiss-born geologist, natural philosopher and meteorologist who spent much of his time working in England. FRSL.

places.name: Ingleborough
places.description: the second-highest mountain in the Yorkshire Dales, England.

places.name: Yorkshire
places.description: Yorkshire is a historic county in northern England and the largest by area size in the United Kingdom.

places.name: England
places.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

places.name: Mont Granier
places.description: a limestone mountain located between the départements of Savoie and Isère in France.

places.name: Alps
places.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

places.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

places.name: Geneva
places.description: Geneva is a city in Switzerland on the border with France.

places.name: Devon
places.description: A county in south-west England.

places.name: Somerset
places.description: A county in south-west England.

places.name: Minehead
places.description: a coastal town and civil parish in Somerset, England

places.name: Devon
places.description: A county in south-west England.

persons.name: Abraham GottlobWerner
persons.description: German geologist who proposed the theory of Neptunism and who also proposed the chronological sequence found in stratified rocks.

persons.name: UlisseAldrovandi
persons.description: Italian naturalist and father of natural history according to Buffon and Linneaus.

places.name: Freiberg
places.description: A university and former mining town in Saxony, Germany

persons.name: CharlesHatchett
persons.description: He made his money from coach building which he used to pursue his interests in chemistry and mineralogy in the course of which he isolated the chemical element now called niobium. He was a Manager of the Royal Institution, playing a key role especially in running its lecture programme during the 1800s. FRSL.

places.name: Alps
places.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

places.name: Pembrokeshire
places.description: A county in the south-west of Wales.

persons.name: Johann JakobScheuchzer
persons.description: Swiss geologist and palaeontologist within a Biblical context. He was a diluvialist and believed that rock strata and fossils were deposited during the Great Flood. His account of the supposed remains of a human who witnessed the flood (Homo Diluvii Testis) was published in Latin in 1726. ForMemRSL.

places.name: Bristol
places.description: A city in south-western England.

places.name: Bath, Somerset
places.description: Bath is a city in the county of Somerset, England, known for and named after its Roman-built baths.

places.name: Linlithgow
places.description: A town in West Lothian, Scotland, lying approximately twenty miles west of Edinburgh. Davy possibly refers to it when he mentions 'Lithgow' in his geological discussion on basalt: The Edinburgh Review notes that '...there is a thin seam of coal below a bed of beautiful columnar basaltes, at Hillhouse lime-quarry, a mile south of Linlithgow' (Vol IX, 1807, p. 69).

places.name: Staffa
places.description: an island of the Inner Hebrides in Argyll and Bute, Scotland.

places.name: Fingal's Cave
places.description: a sea cave on the uninhabited island of Staffa, in the Inner Hebrides of Scotland, known for its natural acoustics.

places.name: Staffa
places.description: an island of the Inner Hebrides in Argyll and Bute, Scotland.

persons.name: Uno vonTroil
persons.description: Swedish traveller and the archbishop of Uppsala. He travelled to Iceland with Joseph Banks.

persons.name: SarahMurray Aust
persons.description: An English travel writer, best known for her Companion and Useful Guide to the Beauties of Scotland (1799). She published under the name The Hon. Mrs. Murray, of Kensington, though after her second marriage she was also known as Sarah Aust.

places.name: Fingal's Cave
places.description: a sea cave on the uninhabited island of Staffa, in the Inner Hebrides of Scotland, known for its natural acoustics.

places.name: County Antrim
places.description: A county in north-eastern Northern Ireland.

places.name: Giant's Causeway
places.description: The Giant's Causeway is an extensive area of columnar basalt in County Antrim, Northern Ireland, formed by an ancient volcanic fissure eruption.

places.name: Isle of Eigg
places.description: Second largest of the Small Isles in the Scottish Inner Hebrides. The Sgurr is a pitchstone rock formation on the island, formed 58 million years ago as the result of a pyroclastic volcanic flow from neighbouring Skye; these rocks are mentioned by Davy in his geology lectures,

places.description: Derbyshire is a county in the East Midlands and includes part of the Peak District.

places.name: Durham, England
places.description: a city in northeast England, south of Newcastle upon Tyne.

places.name: Northumberland
places.description: County in the North East of England. It borders Scotland to the north and the county of Cumbria to the west.

places.name: Alston Moor
places.description: A civil parish in Cumbria, England, based around the small town of Alston.

places.name: Cumberland
places.description: Cumberland is a historic county in the far north-west of England.

places.name: River Tees
places.description: The River Tees, in England, rises on the eastern slope of Cross Fell in the North Pennines and flows eastwards for 85 miles to reach the North Sea in the North East of England.

persons.description: Assisted lecturers at the RI, including making transparencies use in Davy's courses of lectures on geology.
